1.Two Dimensional Wave Equation

How would one describe the movement of a wave? More explicitly, suppose that you have an infinitely thin rubber cloak. This piece of rubber is extremely

precise and tensionly even, so that every molecule(or, infinitesimal amount of local part of the cloak) of the rubber is being pulled by the same force, every time, evenly.

Notice that if the rubber cloak changes its form with ‘‘meaningfully big amount’’, the tension would not be even, thus we need the assumption that total changes of the wave as time passes is not large.

For every point of the cloak, it moves only if there are some curvature at that point. We can think of this as some kind of a trampoline, since trampoline only pushes things up when it has a positive second derivative(i.e., positive curvature). Also, one can educatedly guess that the second derivative of the trampoline is proportional to the amount of force it will provide

upward. (You can get this result much more rigorously, but that’s rather simple and you probably already know why it works.) Therefore, one has
